The King of Random:
Copper pipe is cut with a tubing cutter. It's an inexpensive tool that can be had for about $7 at a hardware store. Bending copper tubing in a small circle can be difficult. But... There is a trick that can be used to do it without kinking it. Install and solder the end cap to one end of an appropriate length of tubing. Fill the tubing with fine sand. Salt well work as well. After completely filled to the very end, cap and solder the other end. Bend as required. Cut off the extra and empty the sand or salt. Vuala, a perfectly bent piece of copper tubing without kinks. And, please. I'm not trying to ba a smartallick. Just old and wise.

If you need a cut off jig for copper pipe,  take two blocks of wood like 2x4 cutoffs, put them in a vice and use that 3/8 drill bit on the seem between the two blocks. You then use that to hold the pipe and saw right next to the wood blocks.

ANYTIME you are drilling through plastic, get the but started then REVERSE THE DRILL. This will cause the but to burn through more than cut, and will prevent breaking the plastic when the bit punches through the other side. This is well known in the construction trades (like vinyl siding installation) and would be helpful for your audience.

For bending small lengths of copper pipe, cap one end, fill it with water and stand it in a freezer so that the expansion doesn't burst the pipe. The ice inside prevents the pipe from collapsing but is fragile enough to still bend by hand.

The copper in the bottom of the orifice you removed from the regulator acts as a filter and it also helps keep tiny spiders out. Oil Burner nozzles have the same thing, sometimes screens depending on the manufacture and the flow rate of the nozzle. If your barbecue sits outside all year, when you clean it in the spring before use, take your orifices out with a 3/8 wrench and use the box end. Don't use vice grips. Tiny little spiders sometimes get in behind the hole and build their little webs.

Just wanted to give you guys a tip when your copper pipe starts to get a bend in it you can use a crescent wrench to try and round It Out by going around the size of the pipe and slowly working with it just a trick to try and help you out or you can buy a cheap pair of spring Benders for five bucks and it will work with copper tubing most of it and help keep it from kinking while bending it..
